wave1.mood_rationale: The patient exhibits profound distress related to coming out to parents, marked by grief, guilt, and fear of rejection. They describe losing the anticipated parental relationship and experiencing anger, but also small yet important positive signals: occasional relief at not having to pretend and explicit self-acceptance (happy with who I am, in therapy). They show somatic signs of depression (chest tightness, exhaustion, decreased appetite) and pervasive rumination about family dynamics and future outcomes (What if they never come around?). There is no active suicidal ideation or plan, but the expressed hopelessness about parental acceptance and the sense of loss indicate significant distress that is not easily managed. The presence of supportive moments (Jordan’s support) introduces a glimmer of resilience, preventing the score from being in the severe range.
mood_indicators: Grief and sense of loss about parental relationship (e.g., 'Grief... grieving the parents I thought I had' and 'I feel like I lost them')
Guilt and self-blame for coming out ('I feel responsible. I caused this. If I had just kept quiet')
Hopelessness about acceptance ('What if they never come around? What if I just lost my family...')
Mixed emotions with some relief and self-acceptance ('at least I don't have to pretend anymore' and 'I'm happy with who I am')
Somatic/depressive symptoms (chest tightness, fatigue, decreased appetite; 'noticing I’m exhausted' and 'I have no appetite')
Supportive interpersonal context (Jordan supportive, 'held me while I cried')
wave1.emotional_tone: distressed, conflicted, grieving with moments of relief and conditional hope
topics: Parental rejection after coming out and family relationship rupture
Ambiguous loss/grief with anger, guilt, and somatic distress
action_items: Respect parents' request for space; delay contacting them for now and reassess timing later
Prioritize self-care: eat regular meals, monitor chest tightness/sleep, lean on Jordan and contact therapist if symptoms worsen
wave1.summary: Client experienced parental rejection after coming out; grieving ambiguous loss, feeling anger and guilt, poor appetite and chest tightness.

symptom_reduction.description: This session reflects an acute spike in distress after coming out: you described persistent chest tightness (“My chest feels tight all the time”), low appetite (“I have no appetite”), and feeling “exhausted.” You did note one stabilizing point—sleep has been “okay… surprisingly”—but overall the dominant pattern is grief/anger/guilt rather than symptom relief.

skill_development.skill: Values-based action (ACT: choosing authenticity despite fear)
skill_development.evidence: You described reaching a point where you “couldn't keep hiding anymore,” and you told your parents clearly who you are and what you need (“I use they/them pronouns now… I’m happy with who I am”), which aligns with acting from values even with anxiety.
You prepared intentionally and communicated directly: “I said I needed to tell them something important… I’m non-binary and pansexual… my name is Alex.”

skill_development.skill: Boundary-respecting and paced responding (tolerating uncertainty/urge management)
skill_development.evidence: Even with the urge to call your dad (“Say something. Anything.”), you recognized you may not be able to tolerate more rejection right now and considered honoring your mom’s request: “my mom said they need space… I don’t know if I can handle more rejection.”
You reached out quickly when you needed help (“I got your text yesterday”) and leaned on Jordan for immediate safety/comfort (“I couldn’t be alone… They just held me while I cried”).

goal_progress.goal: Come out to parents in a values-consistent way while prioritizing safety and support
goal_progress.evidence: You followed through with the planned disclosure from last session: you went home intentionally, disclosed your identity and pronouns, and arranged support/transport with Jordan afterward.

goal_progress.goal: Strengthen boundaries and reduce relationship-related abandonment anxiety
goal_progress.evidence: The parental rupture activated strong abandonment themes (“What if they never come around? What if I just lost my family…”) and an urgent pull to seek reassurance from your dad despite risk of re-injury (“Part of me wants to call my dad…”).

behavioral_changes: Proactively sought support by moving the session up after the disclosure.
Used a support plan in real time (texted Jordan for pickup; stayed with them to avoid being alone).
Considered delaying contact and respecting the boundary your parents set, rather than pushing for immediate resolution.

key_realizations: You named the emotional complexity clearly: anger, guilt, grief, and relief can exist at the same time (“I also feel kind of relieved… at least I don’t have to pretend anymore”).
You identified this as a real loss even though your parents are alive—ambiguous loss (“they’re not dead, but I feel like I lost them”), which validates why the pain feels so destabilizing.

You began separating responsibility from blame: the pain is real, but their acceptance is not something you can control—your honesty did not ‘cause’ their rejection (you voiced self-blame: “I caused this,” and explored the alternative cost of silence: “that’s survival, not living”).
patterns: A recurring theme across your last three sessions is fear of abandonment and the pull to regain closeness when attachment feels threatened (Session 1 in your romantic relationship; Session 2 anticipating parental rejection; Session 3 experiencing real-time parental withdrawal and urgently wanting your dad to respond).

You repeatedly choose connection + authenticity over avoidance: you moved from planning disclosure (Session 2) to completing it (this session), even while expecting it might go badly (“worse than I imagined”).
growth_areas: Strengthening self-protection during ‘high-trigger’ moments: building a step-by-step plan for what you do when guilt spikes and you feel the urge to reach out for reassurance, so you can reduce re-injury while still honoring your need for connection.
Practicing self-compassion language that matches your values: replacing “I ruined everything” with wording that holds both truths—this is painful, and you acted with integrity.
strengths: Courage and clarity: you communicated your identity and needs directly, including pronouns and name, even while terrified.
Emotional insight: you articulated grief with nuance (mourning the parents you wished you had; questioning what love meant; naming ambiguous loss).
Protective decision-making: you chose not to be alone, arranged immediate support, and are considering pacing contact to avoid further harm.
Capacity for empathy without losing yourself: you can understand their cultural context while still acknowledging the impact on you (“It can be hard for them AND you can still be angry”).

learned: Ambiguous loss framing (naming the type of grief)
Urge surfing / pause-and-plan before contacting parents
Self-care stabilization (regular meals, body check-ins for grief/somatic symptoms)
Values-based coping (returning to authenticity and self-respect when guilt shows up)
practice_recommendations: Use a 24–72 hour ‘pause rule’ before initiating contact with your parents: write the message you want to send, save it as a draft, and revisit after your body feels calmer (chest tightness down, appetite at least somewhat present).

Twice daily, do a 2-minute body scan focused on chest/shoulders/jaw. Pair it with slow exhale breathing (longer exhale than inhale) and then ask: ‘What emotion is my body carrying right now—grief, fear, anger, guilt?’ Name it without fixing it.
Meal scaffolding for low appetite: aim for 3 “minimum viable” fuel moments/day (e.g., smoothie, soup, yogurt/toast). Let Jordan’s support count as a strength, not a dependency.

When guilt thoughts appear (“I caused this”), practice a counter-statement aligned with your values: ‘I told the truth. Their reaction is about their capacity right now. I can grieve without blaming myself.’ Repeat it once per guilt spike.

therapeutic_relationship.engagement_evidence: You initiated urgent contact to move the session up, gave a detailed account of the event, and actively explored options about contacting your parents (“Part of me wants to call my dad… but… I don’t know if I can handle more rejection”).
therapeutic_relationship.openness_evidence: You shared vulnerable emotions and self-blaming thoughts (“I feel responsible. I caused this. If I had just kept quiet…”) and described somatic symptoms (“My chest feels tight all the time… I have no appetite”).
therapeutic_relationship.alliance_evidence: You accepted the therapist’s framing and challenged/processed it collaboratively (“I know you’re right. I do. But god, this hurts so much”), and you stayed engaged even when discussing painful content like your mother blaming therapy.

practices: Create a ‘Contact Decision Tree’ for your parents: (1) What is my goal (repair, info, reassurance)? (2) What outcome can I tolerate today? (3) What’s the smallest step that protects me (wait, send a brief neutral check-in later, ask for a timeline, or write unsent letter)? Bring it to next session.

Write two letters: (A) an unsent grief letter to your parents (what you lost, what you wish they could say), (B) a letter to yourself from a protective, loving voice (what you did that was brave; what you deserve now).

If chest tightness increases, add grounding: 5-4-3-2-1 sensory scan + feet-to-floor pressure for 60 seconds. If tightness becomes severe, persistent, or feels medically concerning, seek medical evaluation—grief can be somatic, but you still deserve safety.
Lean on Jordan intentionally: ask for one concrete support daily (eat together, short walk, or a 10-minute ‘just hold me’ check-in) so support is structured rather than only crisis-based.
resources: Worksheet: ‘Ambiguous Loss’ psychoeducation handout (Pauline Boss) — helps normalize grief when someone is physically present but emotionally unavailable.
Book: *The Queer and Transgender Resilience Workbook* (Anneliese Singh) — practical exercises for coping with family rejection and strengthening self-compassion.
Resource: PFLAG — family education materials; even if your parents aren’t ready now, it can be helpful later as a low-pressure option.
Crisis/support (if needed): The Trevor Project (LGBTQ+ support) — for moments when the loneliness or panic spikes outside session.
reflection_prompts: When I say ‘I caused this,’ what am I trying to control or prevent emotionally?
What did authenticity protect me from (emotionally, relationally, spiritually) compared with staying silent?
What are the signs that contacting my parents would be self-honoring vs. self-abandoning?
What does ‘family’ mean to me right now—and what forms of family (chosen/supportive) are already showing up?

wave1.mood_rationale: Overall mood and functioning show a clear upward trajectory with sustained positive coping and social engagement. Positive signals include: improved sleep (6–7 hours per night, fewer panic spirals), better appetite and regular meals, and increased daily activities (meditation, gratitude practices, journaling of three things). The client reports functional gains (attending support group, mom’s supportive message, advisor listening, Jordan’s involvement) and a growing sense of agency (“I’m making choices. I have some control here, even when things feel out of control”). There is also a meaningful shift in perspective toward hope and acceptance: recognizing that others’ journeys take time, feeling “freedom” from ruminative thoughts, and valuing small positive moments. Nonetheless, there remains residual anxiety and fear, occasional hard days, and lingering longing for complete parental acceptance, which prevents a sense of thriving from being complete. No active suicidal ideation is evident, and protective factors (support networks, coping skills) are present.
mood_indicators: Improved sleep pattern (6–7 hours, reduced panic spirals)
Regular appetite and meals; engaging in cooking with partner
Active coping skills: daily meditation, cognitive defusion, gratitude exercises
Increased social and family engagement (support group, mom’s message, advisor listening, Jordan attending)
Growing sense of agency and hope; recognition of progress and protection factors
wave1.emotional_tone: hopeful, resilient, with ongoing but manageable anxiety
topics: Parental acceptance and family processing after coming out
Mindfulness/ACT-based coping for grief, depression, and anxiety
action_items: Complete nightly gratitude journal listing three things before bed
wave1.summary: Alex processing parents' responses to coming out; uses mindfulness/cognitive defusion. Daily 10‑min meditation and nightly 3‑item gratitude practice.

breakthrough_data.label: Self-Validation
breakthrough_data.description: Alex realizes their identity and self-worth are not contingent on their parents’ understanding or approval. They differentiate their own truth from their parents’ process, shifting from external validation to self-validation. This new understanding reduces shame and urgency, creates space for patience with family, and affirms a stable sense of self.
breakthrough_data.evidence: “You mentioned something earlier… ‘I don’t need them to understand me to know who I am.’” (therapist) → Alex: “Yeah. That’s like, the biggest thing I’ve realized. For so long I thought I needed my parents’ approval to be valid… But I know who I am. Their journey to understanding is separate from my truth.” and “Your parents’ confusion doesn’t make you less real… the sky is still blue even if someone is colorblind.”

symptom_reduction.description: Compared to last session’s acute grief/somatic distress, you reported clear stabilization: sleep is now “six to seven hours most nights” with “not the all-night panic spiral anymore,” appetite is “more regularly” with cooking/eating feeling “less impossible,” and anxiety/depression feel “better… not perfect,” with increased ability to “observe the grief without drowning in it.”

skill_development.skill: ACT cognitive defusion (observing thoughts without fusing)
skill_development.evidence: “Thoughts will come up… ‘my dad hates me’… but instead of spiraling, I just notice it… ‘oh, there’s that thought again’… go back to my breath… it makes it less sharp.”

skill_development.skill: Mindfulness practice (daily meditation for emotional regulation)
skill_development.evidence: “I’ve been doing the meditation every morning… just ten minutes. And it’s helping.”

skill_development.skill: Gratitude practice as attention training (depression counter-skill)
skill_development.evidence: “Every night before bed, three things… Jordan’s laugh… my advisor actually listened… my mom’s text… the sunshine.”
“Accepting what is” (without “lowering expectations”), and recognizing “some days are hard… and that doesn’t mean I’m failing.”
You attended an LGBTQ+ support group despite anxiety (“I was so nervous, but… welcoming”), plan to return weekly, and invited ongoing partner support (“Jordan’s coming with me next week too”).

skill_development.skill: Differentiation / self-validation (identity not contingent on parental approval)
skill_development.evidence: “I don’t need them to understand me to know who I am… Their journey… is separate from my truth.”

goal_progress.goal: Cope with post-coming-out distress using ACT/mindfulness while protecting mood stability
goal_progress.evidence: You consistently practiced morning meditation and noticed fewer spirals; you also resumed regular meals and improved sleep.

goal_progress.goal: Strengthen self-worth independent of parental acceptance
goal_progress.evidence: Breakthrough: you separated your identity from your parents’ understanding (“I know who I am”), reducing shame/urgency.

goal_progress.goal: Build supportive connection (partner/community) during family uncertainty
goal_progress.evidence: You joined the campus LGBTQ+ group and described it as “breathing,” with plans for continued attendance and partner involvement.

behavioral_changes: Maintained a daily 10-minute morning meditation routine and used it during triggering thoughts.
Implemented nightly gratitude journaling (3 items) despite difficult days.
Increased social engagement by attending an LGBTQ+ support group and planning weekly return.
Improved self-care routines: more consistent sleep schedule and regular meals/cooking with Jordan.
Shifted language toward agency (“I survived,” “I’m making choices”), indicating a behavioral/cognitive move away from helplessness.

key_realizations: You can grieve the loss of the “fantasy of instant acceptance” while still letting in the reality that your parents may be trying (your mom’s: “We need time to understand. We love you.”).
Your thoughts are not facts: you can notice “my dad hates me” as a passing mental event rather than “the only truth,” which reduced spiraling and increased steadiness.
Progress is non-linear—and non-linearity isn’t failure: “Some days are hard… and that doesn’t mean I’m failing.”
Core breakthrough: your identity and worth are stable even without parental understanding—“I don’t need them to understand me to know who I am… Their journey… is separate from my truth.”
Courage is action with fear present: “I’m scared all the time. I’m just doing it anyway.”
patterns: Across sessions, family acceptance has been a major trigger for anxiety/grief (Session 2: rupture and guilt; this session: ongoing uncertainty). This week, the pattern shifted from urgency/self-blame to patience/self-validation, helped by community perspective (“three years… and they survived”).

A recurring protective factor is relational support—especially Jordan—and you’re increasingly letting that support be steady rather than crisis-only (“They keep showing up… I’m trying to just trust that instead of sabotaging it”).

Language/identity agency has strengthened over time: last session’s emphasis on what happened to you is giving way to active ownership (“I survived… I have some control here”), suggesting growing psychological flexibility.
growth_areas: Strengthen ‘middle path’ contact/communication skills with parents: holding hope while pacing exposure so you don’t re-injure yourself when uncertainty spikes.
Continue building tolerance for receiving love (especially from Jordan/community) without bracing for abandonment—practicing trust in small, repeatable steps.
Refine your defusion practice for self-blame themes (“I ruined everything”) by pairing noticing with a brief self-compassionate reframe, so the thought loses its sting faster.
strengths: Resilience and persistence: “I genuinely didn’t know if I would [survive], and I did,” and you kept showing up to therapy and daily practices.
Emotional maturity/complexity: you held two truths at once—grieving and appreciating effort—without collapsing into all-or-nothing interpretations.
Agency and insight: you noticed the shift from external validation to internal truth and articulated it clearly (“Their journey… is separate from my truth”).
Willingness to be supported: you allowed Jordan to accompany you to group and are practicing trust instead of sabotage.
Meaning-making through metaphor: clouds/sky and colorblindness metaphors show strong reflective capacity—often a marker of durable coping.

learned: ACT cognitive defusion (labeling thoughts as thoughts)
Acceptance of non-linear change / flexible expectations
Community-based support as regulation (support group attendance)
practice_recommendations: Defusion micro-practice (60–90 seconds, 1–3x/day): when a painful thought shows up, say, “I’m having the thought that ____,” then identify the feeling in your body (e.g., tight chest), take 3 slow exhales, and return to what matters in the moment (one small next action).
Keep the 10-minute morning meditation, and add a single sentence afterward: “Today I want to practice being on my own side when ____ shows up.”
On hard gratitude days, allow “minimum viable gratitude”: one sensory detail + one relationship detail + one self-respect detail (e.g., “warm tea,” “Jordan showed up,” “I didn’t chase reassurance”).
Use the support group as a planned regulation tool: before group, name one intention (“I want to feel less alone”); after group, write one takeaway that supports patience with your parents’ process.

therapeutic_relationship.engagement_evidence: You brought specific updates (mom’s text, dad researching, support group), responded thoughtfully to therapist reflections, and explored distinctions like “accepting what is” vs “lowering expectations.”
therapeutic_relationship.openness_evidence: You shared tearful vulnerability (“I cried… for like twenty minutes”), fear of abandonment (“I keep waiting for them to leave”), and self-blame thoughts (“I ruined everything”) alongside deeper identity work.
therapeutic_relationship.alliance_evidence: You collaborated easily with the therapist’s ACT framing (defusion/psychological flexibility), accepted feedback about your language shift (“Whoa. Yeah… I do”), and engaged in deeper exploration of the quote, “I don’t need them to understand me to know who I am.”

practices: Continue: 10-minute morning meditation + nightly 3-item gratitude (as planned). Track with a simple checkbox to reinforce consistency over perfection.

Create a ‘Parent Contact Pace Plan’ for the next 2 weeks: decide what signals mean “wait” (e.g., poor sleep, high chest tightness) vs “small step” (e.g., a brief text to mom only). Bring the plan to next session.

Write a short self-validation script (3–4 lines) to use after any family-related trigger, e.g., “My identity is real. Their pace is about them. I can feel grief and still be steady. Next right step: ____.” Practice it once daily.

Relationship safety rep with Jordan: once this week, share one specific fear (“I’m afraid you’ll leave”) + one specific request (“Can you reassure me by ____?”). Keep it concrete and time-limited (5–10 minutes).
resources: ACT resource: *The Happiness Trap* by Russ Harris — accessible exercises on defusion/acceptance and values-based living.
Support for families: PFLAG guides (easy-to-share PDFs/webpages) — an option if/when your parents are open to structured education.
Mindfulness app (optional): Insight Timer or Headspace — use a consistent 10-minute track to reduce decision fatigue.
reflection_prompts: When I want immediate parental reassurance, what feeling am I trying to escape (shame, fear, loneliness, grief)? What’s one kinder way to meet that feeling?
What does being ‘on my own side’ look like today—in language, boundaries, and how I treat my body (sleep/food)?
What are 3 pieces of evidence that my worth is stable even when someone doesn’t understand me?
What kind of relationship with my parents would feel both hopeful and self-protective over the next 6 months (not forever)?

wave1.mood_rationale: The patient presents with a markedly elevated positive mood across multiple domains, coupled with strong functioning and meaningful engagement in life. Evidence of a sustained upward trajectory includes: academic success (paper accepted, first author) and reduction in imposter feelings, reports of improved sleep, energy, and focus with ADHD medication (Adderall 15 mg), and active use of grounding techniques (box breathing, sleep hygiene, exercise) that correlate with better mood and productivity. They describe healthier romantic relationships, increased social activity, and a sense of meaning through mentoring LGBTQ+ students. They note family validation (dad’s text) and emotional moments of connection (crying with support). Objective symptom measures are favorable (PHQ-9 = 7, GAD-7 = 7), suggesting mild current distress. However, they also acknowledge potential relapse risk and maintain a realistic plan to monitor symptoms and seek support if needed, including concern about future volatility and fear of relapse. Overall, the balance of evidence indicates a high positive mood with some residual anxiety, hence a score in the very positive range with cautious optimism.
mood_indicators: Academic achievement: paper accepted and first-author status
Significant reduction in anxiety and panic symptoms since earlier sessions
Improved sleep, routines, and energy (sleep hygiene, regular bedtime, exercise, focus with medication)
Engagement in meaningful roles: mentoring queer students, sense of purpose
Strong social support and relational closeness (Jordan, Sarah, Marcus; dad expressing pride)
wave1.emotional_tone: energized, hopeful, proud with cautious optimism and some residual worry about relapse
topics: Relapse prevention and warning-sign action plan
ADHD medication stabilization with grounding and behavioral strategies
action_items: Create a wellness/relapse-prevention plan before the next session listing warning signs and specific action steps
Continue meeting with LGBTQ+ student mentees and maintain coping routines (box breathing, sleep hygiene, exercise)
wave1.summary: Patient in remission; created relapse-prevention plan, continues Adderall 15mg, grounding/box breathing, sleep hygiene, exercise, and peer mentoring.

symptom_reduction.description: You described a major drop in anxiety/panic and depressive interference compared with earlier sessions: "I couldn't even open my laptop without having a panic attack" → now "publishing papers and mentoring other students." You also reported improved sleep and energy from consistent sleep hygiene ("I go to bed at the same time every night, I don't scroll on my phone in bed"), return to exercise ("running a couple times a week"), and much better day-to-day functioning. Your symptom measures corroborate this: PHQ-9 = 7 and GAD-7 = 7, down from January (PHQ-9 18, GAD-7 16), and your therapist explicitly labeled this as remission.

skill_development.skill: Cognitive restructuring / responding to imposter-syndrome thoughts
skill_development.evidence: "I keep waiting for someone to tell me there was a mistake. But then I remember that's my old brain talking... The imposter syndrome stuff we've been working on. I actually did this."

skill_development.skill: Grounding + box breathing for anxiety/attachment activation
skill_development.evidence: "When I start feeling anxious, I actually use those grounding techniques we practiced instead of texting them a million times." and "The box breathing, for sure."

skill_development.skill: Relapse prevention (early warning sign identification + action planning)
skill_development.evidence: You named personalized warning signs ("sleeping a lot again," "stopped wanting to see Jordan or my friends," "avoiding my research or missing deadlines," "intrusive thoughts about being worthless") and generated a concrete response plan ("reach out to Jordan or Sarah or Marcus," medication consistency/psychiatry check-in, "call you to schedule a session").
"I've been really good about my sleep schedule... I go to bed at the same time every night... It's made such a difference in my mood and energy."
"They asked if I'd be willing to mentor other queer students in STEM... I've already met with two students and it's been really rewarding."

skill_development.skill: Secure communication / reduced reassurance-seeking in relationship
skill_development.evidence: "We actually talk about things when there's an issue instead of me just spiraling."

goal_progress.goal: Reduce depression/anxiety symptoms and restore academic functioning
goal_progress.evidence: PHQ-9 and GAD-7 both 7 with therapist noting remission; functioning shift from panic blocking laptop use to "first author" acceptance and advisor noticing productivity.

goal_progress.goal: Strengthen self-worth independent of external validation (parents/advisors)
goal_progress.evidence: You recognized and answered the old approval-seeking narrative: "that's my old brain talking" and "I actually did this." This builds directly on the prior self-validation breakthrough (identity/worth not contingent on parents).

goal_progress.goal: Create a relapse-prevention/wellness plan to maintain gains
goal_progress.evidence: You and your therapist began identifying warning signs and action steps; homework assigned: "create a wellness action plan" with protective routines, warning signs, and concrete steps.

goal_progress.goal: Build supportive connection and reduce abandonment-driven spirals
goal_progress.evidence: You described increased closeness and more secure relating with Jordan, plus active social engagement with Sarah/Marcus ("hanging out more, going to trivia nights").

behavioral_changes: Re-engaged academically at a high level (paper accepted; first author).
Reduced reassurance-seeking behaviors by substituting grounding/box breathing when anxious with Jordan.
Maintained a consistent bedtime routine and limited phone use in bed (sleep hygiene).
Returned to regular exercise (running a couple times/week).
Expanded social connection (more time with friends; trivia nights).
Stepped into a meaningful role mentoring LGBTQ+ students, increasing purpose and identity integration.
Proactively planned for maintenance by identifying relapse warning signs and next-step actions.

key_realizations: You can recognize "old brain" narratives (imposter syndrome) without letting them run the show—then anchor to evidence and self-credit: "I actually did this."

Remission isn’t a fluke; it’s the predictable result of consistent behaviors and supports. You took in the idea that you’re "actually better" and connected it to your effort (therapy homework, medication adherence, routines, support).
Your fear of relapse is not a sign you’re failing—it’s a signal your system is learning to protect what you’ve built. You turned that fear into planning: warning signs + action steps.

Family change can be real even when it’s incomplete. Your dad’s text ("Proud of your paper. Still learning about... everything.") landed as a meaningful acknowledgment while you stayed realistic ("I'm not holding my breath").
You’re shifting from surviving to contributing: mentoring queer students transformed past pain into purpose ("really meaningful" and "rewarding").
patterns: Longitudinal shift from acute grief/somatic distress (earlier chest tightness, low appetite, panic) toward stability and agency: earlier sessions centered on ambiguous loss and fear of abandonment; this session shows reclaimed functioning, enjoyment, and a forward-looking maintenance plan (biweekly transition).

A consistent protective factor across sessions is connection—especially Jordan. Earlier, Jordan provided crisis holding; now you’re using skills to stay regulated inside the relationship (less spiraling, more communication), suggesting stronger attachment security over time.

Your growth follows a clear sequence: validation and stabilization → ACT-style defusion/self-validation → consolidation/relapse prevention. This session marks the consolidation phase (keeping gains through maintenance routines and early-intervention steps).
growth_areas: Build a relapse plan that’s specific enough to use when you’re foggy—especially around the first subtle shifts (sleep changes, avoidance, withdrawal). You’re already identifying signs; the next growth step is making the plan even more ‘plug-and-play.’

Practice ‘celebrating without bracing.’ You’re allowing pride, but part of you still waits for the drop ("waiting for someone to tell me there was a mistake," worry it will "fall apart"). Strengthening your capacity to hold success without anticipating punishment will protect mood stability.
Continue balancing hope with boundaries in family dynamics: staying open to your dad’s incremental progress while protecting yourself from over-investing in rapid change.
strengths: Insight and metacognition: you catch patterns in real time ("that's my old brain talking").
Consistency and follow-through: sustained routines (sleep hygiene, exercise, coping practice) and medication adherence that directly support remission.
Relational maturity: you’re communicating and regulating in relationship instead of escalating reassurance cycles ("talk about things" vs. "spiraling").
Meaning-making and leadership: mentoring shows courage and generosity—turning lived experience into support for others.
Emotional openness: you allowed yourself to fully feel the impact of your dad’s text ("full-on sobbed") and responded with warmth and realism.

learned: Relapse prevention planning (warning signs + action steps)
Maintenance mindset (continuing coping routines when you feel well)
practice_recommendations: Write your Wellness/Relapse Plan on one page and keep it somewhere visible (notes app + printed copy). Include: (1) green-zone routines (sleep, exercise, mentoring, social), (2) yellow-zone warning signs you listed (sleeping more, social withdrawal, avoidance, intrusive worthlessness/abandonment thoughts), (3) exact actions within 24–48 hours (text Jordan/Sarah/Marcus a scripted message; schedule therapy; medication consistency; psychiatrist check-in if needed).

Create a ‘2-day rule’ for avoidance: if you avoid research/admin tasks for 2 consecutive days, you shift into yellow-zone actions automatically (reach out + schedule support + do one 20-minute starter block).
Keep box breathing as a daily maintenance rep: 2 minutes once/day when calm, so it stays automatic under stress.
Add a brief ‘credit practice’ after wins: write 3 bullets—what you did, what skill it reflects, who supported you—so pride becomes embodied rather than fleeting.

therapeutic_relationship.engagement_evidence: You arrived with many updates, responded actively to questions, collaborated on warning signs and a step-by-step plan, and thoughtfully considered the move to biweekly sessions ("I think it's a good idea").
therapeutic_relationship.openness_evidence: You shared vulnerable emotions ("I cried... full-on sobbed"), fears ("scared that it's all going to fall apart"), and specific past behaviors ("texting them a million times") without minimizing.
therapeutic_relationship.alliance_evidence: The dialogue shows trust and collaboration: you took in reflections (imposter syndrome reframing; remission), co-created a relapse-prevention plan, and negotiated a treatment-structure change with reassurance and flexibility (biweekly with option to increase if needed).

practices: Complete the one-page Wellness/Relapse-Prevention Plan before next session, including: warning signs, 24-hour actions, 1-week actions, and ‘when to escalate’ (therapy sooner, psychiatrist check-in, urgent support).

Draft 2 short ‘help-seeking scripts’ you can copy/paste when you’re sliding (one to Jordan; one to Sarah/Marcus): e.g., “I’m noticing some yellow-flag signs (sleep/avoidance). Can you check in with me tonight and help me stay on my routine?”

Maintain your core stabilizers as non-negotiables during the biweekly transition: consistent bedtime/wake time, 2 runs/week (or equivalent movement), and 2 social touchpoints/week (friend or mentor meeting counts).
Do a weekly 5-minute review: rate sleep, avoidance, social connection, and intrusive self-worth thoughts from 0–10; if two areas worsen for 2 weeks, implement yellow-zone actions immediately.
resources: Worksheet: Relapse Prevention Plan / Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP) — a structured template for early warning signs and action steps.
Book (skills refresher): *The Happiness Trap* by Russ Harris — supports your ongoing defusion/self-validation work as you consolidate gains.
App (optional, for routine support): Daylio or Moodnotes — quick tracking of sleep/routines/warning signs without heavy journaling.
reflection_prompts: When I notice the thought “this will fall apart,” what is it trying to protect me from—and what would a steady, compassionate response sound like?
What are my top 5 ‘green-zone’ behaviors that make relapse less likely—and which one slips first when I’m stressed?
How do I want to stay connected to my dad’s ‘trying’ without making my wellbeing depend on his pace?
